title: Investors jump into tracker funds as markets turn
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Fri, Oct 9, 2015, 18:18 BST - UK Markets closed Investors jump into tracker funds as markets turn By Ed Monk | Telegraph – 42 minutes ago 0NC5.L 0.00 
Investing platform Interactive Investor said that five of the top 10 most traded funds on its platform are now trackers 
More investors are opting to shun fund managers in favour of lower-cost tracker funds, according to trading data. 
Investing platform Interactive Investor said that five of the top 10 most traded funds on its platform in the past three months have been “passive” tracker funds. 
A year ago just one made it into the top 10. 
Trackers do not have a manager to pick stocks but instead replicate the performance of the index as a whole and regularly rebalance to ensure it moves in line with the market. 
Passive investments now represent over 25pc of net monthly sales, Interactive Investor (LSE: 0NC5.L - news ) said. 
All five best-selling tracker fund on interactive investor are from Vanguard, an asset manager that is renowned for passive investing. Two are from its LifeStratrgy range which blend shares and bonds according to a specified split. 
The rise in tracker sales has coincided with a turn in global stock market since May and it could be a sign investors are jumping on board at the wrong time. 
• Newsletter: Get a weekly round-up of investment ideas 
Trackers tend to do best, relative to actively managed funds, when markets are rising. This increases all share prices and makes it harder for stock-pickers to find winners. Prolonged stock market weakness could see trackers fall behind. 
Over the long term, however, there is evidence that investors do better by sticking to tracker funds because it is impossible to know which active fund managers will beat the market. 
Active funds are more expensive, typically charging 0.85pc on an ongoing basis versus 0.1pc or less for the cheapest trackers. When viewed on a total return basis, this lower cost helps trackers to perform better. Top 10 most traded funds: 01 July 30 September 2015 - Trackers in bold 1. Woodford Equity Income 2. AXA Framlington Biotech 3. Fundsmith Equity 4. Vanguard LifeStrategy 80pc Equity 5. Neptune UK Mid Cap 6. Vanguard FTSE UK All Share Index 7. Vanguard LifeStrategy 100pc Equity 8. Artemis Global Income 9. Vanguard LifeStrategy 60pc Equity 10. Vanguard FTSE Deloped World Ex-UK Rebecca O’Keeffe, head of investment at Interactive Investor, said: “As you move into a different stage of the economic cycle and markets become more volatile, active management may have a greater role to play. 
“Investors should potentially be wary of using either active or passive funds exclusively, as they both have their strengths at different stages of the economic cycle.” 
She (Munich: SOQ.MU - news ) added that prices of the largest global companies, in the FTSE 100, had been moving out of step with those of smaller firms during the recent market volatility. 
This, she said, should prompt passive investors to look beyond large cap tracker funds.
